qas.question: Who recorded the album School's Out?
Tres Hombres is the name of an album by what band?
Who was the lead singer of Montrose?
Kiss' double live album Alive! came out in what year?
Who had a hit single with "(Don't Fear) The Reaper"?
What British born singer achieved success with the album School's Out?
Who was the first British rock band to Challenge the American dominance of the hard rock genre?
What band did Alice Cooper mimic?
What year was Toys in the Attic by Blue Oyster Cult produced?
How high on the billboard charts did the song (Don't Fear) The Reaper by Journey reach?

context: In the United States, macabre-rock pioneer <a0_0><b5_0>Alice Cooper<b5_0/><a0_0/> achieved mainstream success with the top ten album School's Out (1972). In the following year blues rockers <a1_0>ZZ Top<a1_0/> released their classic album Tres Hombres and Aerosmith produced their eponymous début, as did Southern rockers Lynyrd Skynyrd and proto-punk outfit New York Dolls, demonstrating the diverse directions being pursued in the genre. <b6_0>Montrose<b6_0/>, including the instrumental talent of Ronnie Montrose and vocals of <a2_0>Sammy Hagar<a2_0/> and arguably the first all American hard rock band to challenge the British dominance of the genre, released their first album in 1973. <b7_0>Kiss<b7_0/> built on the theatrics of Alice Cooper and the look of the New York Dolls to produce a unique band persona, achieving their commercial breakthrough with the double live album Alive! in <a3_0>1975<a3_0/> and helping to take hard rock into the stadium rock era. In the mid-<b8_0>1970s<b8_0/> Aerosmith achieved their commercial and artistic breakthrough with Toys in the Attic (1975), which reached number 11 in the American album chart, and Rocks (1976), which peaked at number three. <a4_0>Blue Öyster Cult<a4_0/>, formed in the late 60s, picked up on some of the elements introduced by Black Sabbath with their breakthrough live gold album On Your Feet or on Your Knees (1975), followed by their first platinum album, Agents of Fortune (1976), containing the hit single "(Don't Fear) The Reaper", which reached <b9_0>number 12<b9_0/> on the Billboard charts. Journey released their eponymous debut in 1975 and the next year Boston released their highly successful début album. In the same year, hard rock bands featuring women saw commercial success as Heart released Dreamboat Annie and The Runaways débuted with their self-titled album. While Heart had a more folk-oriented hard rock sound, the Runaways leaned more towards a mix of punk-influenced music and hard rock. The Amboy Dukes, having emerged from the Detroit garage rock scene and most famous for their Top 20 psychedelic hit "Journey to the Center of the Mind" (1968), were dissolved by their guitarist Ted Nugent, who embarked on a solo career that resulted in four successive multi-platinum albums between Ted Nugent (1975) and his best selling Double Live Gonzo (1978).
